text:
Fish & Shellﬁsh Immunology (2001) 11, 303—315
doi:10.1006/fsim.2000.0315

Available online at http://www.idealibrary.com on ""%|.®

Immunomodulatory effects of dietary intake of chitin
on gilthead seabream (Sparus aurata L.) innate
immune system

M. A. ESTEBAN, A. CUESTA, J. ORTUNO AND J. MEsEGUER*

Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Biology, University of Murcia,
30100 Murcia, Spain

(Received 2 June 2000, accepted after revision 10 October 2000)

To determine the effects of chitin (poly [1—>4]-,8-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine) on
the innate immune response of gilthead seabream (Sparus aurata L.), ﬁsh were
fed diets containing 0 mg (control), 25, 50 or 100 mg kg ’ 1 chitin for 2, 4 and 6
weeks. Lysozyme and natural haemolytic complement activities, together with
head-kidney leucocyte respiratory burst, phagocytic and cytotoxic activities,
were studied at each of the assayed times. Lysozyme activity was unaffected by
the administration of chitin. The innate humoral and cellular immune
response activities assayed were enhanced by the dietary intake of chitin,
each increasing at a different time: natural haemolytic complement activity
and cytotoxic activity after 2 weeks of treatment, respiratory burst activity
from 4 weeks and phagocytic activity after 6 weeks, although, unlike the other
activities, no statistically signiﬁcant differences were observed in the ﬁrst.
The results indicate that chitin increases the activity of the seabream innate
immune system, and its use as an immunostimulant is discussed, especially
with regards to the protective role. it). 2001 Academic Press

Key words: chitin, immunostimulation, innate immune response, leucocytes,
phagocytosis, cytotoxicity, gilthead seabream (Sparus aurata L.).

 
 
    
 

I. Introduction

   

Many substances from different sources (bacterial components, chemical
agents, animal or plant extracts etc) have been studied as prospective
immunostimulants for ﬁsh (reviewed by Sakai, 1999), and some have been
reported to confer a degree of protection against several diseases commonly
found in farmed ﬁsh, such as Vibrio anguillarum, Aeromonas salmonicida or
Yersinia ruckeri (Kajita et al., 1990; Raa et al., 1992; Baulny et al., 1996; Mulero
et al., 1998). Of these substances obtained from natural sources (which, besides
possessing other interesting properties, are non—toxic, biodegradable and
biocompatible), chitin and chitosan (de-N-aceylated chitin) have received
little attention with regard to ﬁsh (Anderson & Siwicki, 1994; Kawakami ez al.,
1998; Esteban et al., 2000) compared to other substances like vitamins or
glucans (Hardie et al., 1991; Blazer, 1992; Chen & Ainsworth, 1992; Jeney &
Anderson, 1993; Thompson et al., 1993; Robertsen et al., 1994; Ortuﬁo et al.,
